questions.question: During her antenatal ward rounds, an intern noticed a USG report indicating the presence ofjust one kidney in the fetus. Which of the following association would be expected to be seenin the baby?

A 10-month-old female is brought to the clinic with a 102° F fever for 2 days. The mother saysthat she also cries during urination. The history is significant for similar episodes in the pastwhich were treated with antibiotics. Urine analysis shows nitrite-positivity and gram-negativebacteria are seen on urine microscopy. Which of the following anomaly is most commonlyassociated with this child's condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of recurrent urinary tract infection. The most commonanomaly associated with this condition in children is vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).VUR usually is congenital and often familial. It is more common in females. It occurs when thesubmucosal tunnel between the mucosa and detrusor muscle is short or absent.The image below shows VUR gradingMinorcalyxPapilla.FornixGrades of vesicoureteric refluxNormalMajorcalyxRenalpelvisUreterBladderGrade EVesicoureteriorefluxVUR into the non-dilated ureterRRGrade II:VUR into the non-dilated ureter,renal pelvis and calycesGrade II:VUR into the dilated ureter and/orblunting of calyceal fornices.Grade IV:VUR into the grossly dilated ureterwith blunting of calyceal fornicesGrade ViMassive VUR, with significantureteral dilatation and tortuosity.and loss of papillary impression.OMARROW

questions.question: A pediatrician suspects vesicoureteric reflux in a girl with a history of recurrent urinary tractinfections. What is the investigation of choice to confirm this condition?
questions.explanation: Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) is the investigation of choice for vesicoureteral reflux.Recurrent febrile urinary tract infections in a child should raise the suspicion of an anatomicaldefect like vesicoureteric reflux as the cause. Compared to other investigations, a VCUG providesmore anatomic information. It can demonstrate:531• Vesicoureteral reflux•• Duplex collecting system.Ectopic ureter•Paraureteral (bladder) diverticulum•Bladder outlet obstruction•Signs of voiding dysfunction, such as a spinning top urethra

questions.question: Which of the following is the first-line imaging investigation done in a child presenting withan episode of UTI?
questions.explanation: In a child presenting with an episode of urinary tract infection (UTI), initial imaging should beultrasonography of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder.A voiding cystourethrogram is indicated only if the ultrasound study is abnormal, the patient hasatypical features or after a recurrent febrile UTI.DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) scan may be done after 4-6 months of acute infection as it mayhelp to locate and delineate the scarring

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common cause of urinary tract infection in children?
questions.explanation: Urinary tract infections in children are most commonly caused by the following:• Escherichia coli (Most common)⚫ Klebsiella species•• Proteus species•Staphylococcus saprophyticus• Enterococcus• Adenovirus and other viral infections (cause cystitis and gross hematuria)

questions.question: A mother is concerned that her 1-year-old daughter has been having repeated episodes of UTIsince birth. The pediatrician ordered a voiding cystourethrogram, which revealed reflux ofurine into the upper collecting systems without any dilation. Under which grade ofvesicoureteral reflux will this presentation be classified?
questions.explanation: Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) severity is graded according to the appearance of the urinary tract ona contrast voiding cystourethrogram.It is classified into 5 grades (Grade I to V):Grading of vesicoureteral re■ ux:• Grade I- VUR into a non-dilated ureter•Grade II- VUR into the upper collecting system without dilation• Grade III- VUR into the dilated ureter and/or blunting of calyceal fornices.532•Grade IV- VUR into a grossly dilated ureter• Grade V- Massive VUR, with significant ureteral dilation and tortuosity and loss of the papillaryimpression.Minorcalyx-Papilla-FornixGrades of vesicoureteric refluxNormalMajorcalyxUreterRenalpelvisGrade EVesicouretericrefluxVUR into the non-dilated ureterRRBunnng offorficGrade It:VUR into the non-dilated ureter,renal pelvis and calycesGradeIIE:VUR into the dilated ureter and/orblunting of calyceal fornices.RRGrade IV:VUR into the grossly dilated ureterwith blunting of calyceal fornicesGrade ViMassive VUR, with significantureteral dilatation and tortuosity.and loss of papillary impression.OMARROW

questions.question: Ashi, a 12-year-old girl presented with features of hematuria, headache, and blurring ofvision. Her past history is significant for recurrent UTI. On examination, she was found tohave a BP of 150/110 mmHg. Investigations revealed mild renal scarring and urine analysisshowed broad casts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.C: Posterior urethral valve with chronic renal failure
options.D: Reflux uropathy with chronic renal failure

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of reflux uropathy with chronic renal failure.The pathogenesis of vesicoureteral reflux is as follows:Reflux NephropathyVesicoureteral refluxTransport of bacteria from thebladder to upper urinary tractMARecurrent UTI(pyelonephritis)Renal scarring andloss of parenchymaOMARROWLoss of renal parenchyma and renal scarring reduces renal function significantly. This renalinsufficiency leads to renin-mediated hypertension and further progresses to end-stage renaldisease.Re■ux nephropathy remains a common cause of hypertension in children.533Broad casts or renal failure casts are associated with end-stage renal disease.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common cause of abdominal mass in neonates?
questions.explanation: Multicystic dysplastic kidney (MCDK) is the most common cause of an abdominal mass in thenewborn but is mostly non-palpable at birth.In most cases, it is discovered incidentally during prenatal sonography. In some patients, the cystsare identified prenatally, but the cysts regress in utero, and no kidney is identified on imaging atbirth. MCDK is usually unilateral and generally not inherited, unlike polycystic kidney disease(PKD). Contralateral hydronephrosis is present in 5-10% of patients.

questions.question: Komal, a high school student developed a fever after she came back from a trip with herfriends. She also complained about pain while urinating. She says she has been having theseepisodes frequently for the past few years. Her father and her grandfather are a known case ofcystic kidney disease. Her urine analysis is indicative of UTI with hematuria. Renalultrasound was done and its findings are shown below. Which of the following chromosomesare associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: The presence of multiple cysts seen on the ultrasound(image) along with a positive family historypoint towards the diagnosis of autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease. Chromosomes 16and 4 are associated with this condition.Autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease inheritance:Chromosome invoChr16 short armChr 4 long armlvedGenePKD 1Protein encodedPolycystin 1PKD 2Polycystin 2FunctionTransmembrane glycoprot Non-selective cation channelSeen inein85%10-15 %

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is not associated with the lesion seen in the image?
questions.explanation: The given image shows a horseshoe kidney. It is not associated with the posterior urethral valve.Horseshoe kidney is the most common congenital anomaly of the kidneys.Horseshoe kidney is caused due to the fusion of the lower poles of the kidney. The lower border ofthe kidneys usually lie in front of L3 vertebra due to arrest of ascent.The common associations of horseshoe kidney are:• Vesicoureteral reflux• Wilms tumor• Multicystic dysplastic kidney• Turner's syndrome534

questions.question: A young girl presents with the complaints of continuous dribbling of urine. However, she alsovoids normally. Her parents tell you that she had never been totally dry since her birth. Whatis the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The clinical presentation of a young girl with continuous dribbling of urine, despite normalvoiding, strongly suggests the diagnosis of an ectopic ureter.An ectopic ureter refers to a condition where the ureter drains outside the bladder. It is morecommon in females and opens either into the urethra below the sphincter or into the vagina.Hence, they present with constant urinary dripping all day, even though the child voids regularly(paradoxical incontinence).The terminal part of the ureter is frequently narrowed, leading to hydroureteronephrosis. Urinarytract infections (UTIs) are common due to urinary stasis.In males, ectopic ureters usually enter the posterior urethra above the external sphincter, hencethey are usually continent and most patients present with UTI or epididymitis.Investigations include renal ultrasound (USG), voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG), and renal scanto assess function. USG shows a hydronephrotic kidney or dilated upper pole and ureter. If thereis a satisfactory function, the recommended treatment options are ureteral reimplantation intothe bladder or ureteroureterostomy. The poor function may require partial or total nephrectomy.Other options:Option B: A ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter, typically obstructive due to asmall ureteral opening. In childhood, they commonly present with infections. Larger ureterocelescan cause obstruction at the bladder neck.Option C: Congenital megaureter (dilated ureter) presents UTI, urinary stones, hematuria, andflank pain because of urinary stasis.Option D: Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is characterized by the retrograde flow of urine from thebladder to the ureter and kidney. They usually present with recurrent attacks of UTI.

questions.question: 528A 3 yr old male child with left flank pain is diagnosed to have an acute UTI. On USG, the leftureter was found to be duplicated. The most probable site of the opening of ectopic ureter willbe?
questions.explanation: Opening of the ectopic ureter in male (most to least common) :• Posterior urethra (prostatic) above the external sphincter• Seminal vesicle• Prostatic utricle•⚫ Ejaculatory duct• Vas deferens

questions.question: A newborn is being evaluated for anuria. Imaging reveals renal agenesis and pulmonaryhypoplasia. The delivery was complicated due to oligohydramnios. Which of the following isthe most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: 535A newborn infant with anuria, renal agenesis, and pulmonary hypoplasia, with a history ofoligohydramnios, is suggestive of Potter's sequencePotter's sequence is characterized by the triad of:• Renal agenesis•⚫ Oligohydramnios•Pulmonary hypoplasiaMEvents in Potter sequenceBilateral renal agenesis orbilateral multicysticdysplastic kidneysReduced fetalurine excretionOligohydramnios causingfetal compressionRPotter facies:Low-set ears- Beaked noseProminent epicanthicfolds- Downwardslant to eyes©MARROWPulmonary hypoplasiacausingrespiratory failureLimb deformitiesOption B: Pierre-Robin syndrome: micrognathia, retrognathia, glossoptosis.Option C: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia: It can present with pulmonary hypoplasia but otherfeatures like renal agenesis, anuria will not be seen.Option D: CHARGE syndrome: Coloboma of the eye, Heart anomaly, choanal Atresia,Retardation, Genital and Ear anomalies.

questions.question: Antenatal hydronephrosis due to PUJ obstruction is defined as the anteroposterior diameterof the renal pelvis of more thanin the third trimester.
questions.explanation: Anteroposterior diameter of the renal pelvis of >7 to 7.5 mm in the third trimester denotesantenatal hydronephrosis due to pelvic ureteric junction (PUJ) obstruction.Definition of antenatal hydronephrosis by anteroposterior diameter:Degree of antenatal hydronephrosisSecond trimestThird trimestererMildModerateSevere4 to <7 mm7 to ≤10 mm>10 mm7 to <9 mm9 to ≤15 mm>15 mm536

questions.question: Hepatic fibrosis is associated with
questions.explanation: Hepatic and periportal fibrosis is associated with autosomal-recessive polycystic kidney disease(ARPKD)Systemic manifestations of cystic kidney diseasesCystic condition of kidneyAutosomal dominant polycystic kidney diseaseAssociationsLiver cystsCerebral aneurysmsHypertensionMitral valve prolapseKidney stones UTIsAutosomal recessive polycyst Hepatic fibrosis Pulmonary hic kidney diseaseAcquired cystic kidney diseasNephronophthisisypoplasia HypertensionRetinal degeneration, neurologic malformations, skeletal malformations, hepatic malformations, cardiac malformationsMedullary cystic kidney disea Hyperuricemia, goutse

questions.question: Ask-Upmark kidney refers to
questions.explanation: The Ask-Upmark kidney is also termed segmental hypoplasia.Renal segmental hypoplasia:• Severe segmental renal atrophy with loss of parenchymal elements in small kidneys is commonlyknown as segmental hypoplasia.•It refers to small kidneys, usually weighing not more than 35 g.• The scars are seen as cortical depressions overlying shrunken medullary pyramids and theirdilated calyces, and they are characterized histologically by colloid-filled tubular microcysts and apaucity or absence of glomeruli.• Most patients are 10 years or older at diagnosis and have severe hypertension.•Nephrectomy usually controls the hypertension.537
